data.text: Contents
Secondary transfers for burns patients will still follow direct clinical referral to BICU....9
Introduction

To allow medical, nursing, technical, fire crew, security and portering personnel to understand their roles and responsibilities and ensure the safe transfer of patients from  the  helideck to  the relevant hospital department  [Emergency Department, General Intensive Care Unit (GICU) or Burns Intensive Care Unit (BICU)]:
The overall aim of the helideck is to provide a safe facility for the landing and take-off of HEMS helicopters.
To provide improved care access for patients improving the timeliness of the care they can receive.
To enable primary transfer of patients to the Emergency Department (ED) for  definitive care.
To enable secondary transfer of patients to general intensive care unit (GICU)
To enable primary burn patient transfers via ED to burns intensive care unit ( BICU) and secondary transfer of patients direct to BICU
To allow secondary transfer of patients from Broomfield Hospital to specialist clinical units with  dedicated helicopter facilities
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
The operational capabilities of the helideck are covered by the Helideck Standard Operating Procedure (SOP);

The Trust's helideck service provides a safe environment for helimed  operators to land helicopters according to the disclosed limitations of the  helideck opening hours and the weight and class of aircraft according to the helideck SOP. The helideck staffs also assist with the transfer of patients within the hospital building after landing or onward transfer by helicopter of existing inpatients to the Trust;
Many different professional groups may be required to use the helideck and by doing so, must adhere to this Service Policy and Broomfield Hospital Helideck SOP. These groups include:
GICU provides elective and emergency care. Relatively few secondary transfers will be performed to, or from, GICU with the aid of an air ambulance;
BICU takes referrals from all over the UK, for both adults and children. Some notified primary and secondary transfers will be performed via an air ambulance;
Every referral will be scrutinised by a consultant to determine whether the patient  would benefit from air ambulance patient transfer and care will be in line with best practice;
Critically ill children are usually retrieved by the CATS team but may be secondarily transferred by an air transfer service competent in the transfer of children.
Definitions

table_items.text: Department of Electrical and Biomedical Engineering

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Fire Safety Group

4.1.1 On behalf of the Trust's Health & Safety Management Group, the Fire Safety Group will act and be recognised for all statutory and regulatory purposes as the Group responsible for Fire Safety within the Trust and shall scrutinise or investigate any areas covered within its Terms of Reference as agreed by the Board.

4.1.2 It may seek internal and external information and all employees are directed to co- operate.  The  Group  may  seek  outside  external  or  otherwise  independent professional advice and legal opinion.
Helideck Operations Manager

4.2.1  Overall responsibility to manage all staff employed within the Helideck Fire & rescue Service to maintain an immediate and efficient landing facility for the Helicopter Emergency Medical Services wishing to use the Broomfield Hospital Helideck and to ensure that there are means to provide an immediate response to any Helideck related emergency.
Helideck Fire Officer
4.3.1 To be in operational command of a watch and provide an immediate and efficient response to any helideck related emergency.
4.3.2 To provide, by extraneous duties, an effective RFFS helideck operation and to be available to provide an advisory service for local authority fire services.

4.3.3 The Helideck Fire Officer/Lead Helideck Fire Fighter are responsible for the safety and welfare of the duty watch. They are to ensure that there is a safe and efficient operating environment. This will be achieved through the effective management of the duty watch and with close liaison with all other helideck agencies and operatives.
Lead Helideck Fire Fighter /Helideck Fire Fighter
4.4.1 To provide as part of a watch an immediate and efficient response to any helideck related emergency.
4.4.2 To provide as a member of a team, by extraneous duties, an effective helideck operation and to be available to provide an advisory service for local authority fire services.
They are to ensure that any deficiency in PPE is reported immediately to the Helideck Manager.
They are to be aware of all safety requirements needed in a helideck operation.
They are to ensure that all equipment is operated in a safe and competent manner as trained.
They are to ensure that they are physically fit to perform the range of duties commensurate with their employment and they are to ensure that they are current to all mandatory medical requirements.
They must ensure that they are familiar with the contents of the Helideck Standard Operations Policy
To adhere and comply with all matters on the Helideck concerning the Health
& Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 and the Management of Health & Safety at Work Regulations1999.
To operate effectively all firefighting equipment and to report and record any deficiencies to the Helideck Manager
To respond to all Helideck emergencies as part of a duty watch.
To ensure that they are competent in the operation of all associated helideck equipment including helideck lighting.
To ensure that documentation for all activities is completed immediately on completion of task.
Ensure that all tests and inspections of specialised equipment are carried out as laid down in CAA Regulated Documents, Fire Service Drill Book or manufacturers hand book.
Perform snow-clearing duties as and when required.
Carry out safety and surface inspections when required.
Be proficient in the administration of Emergency First Aid and render First Aid when required.
Visual security checking of helicopter panels, doors, passenger safety helmets and straps before helicopter departures.
Calling and locking off the helideck lift.
Preparation of the medical trolley and medical equipment as trained for.
Cleaning specified medical equipment between missions.
Supervision of patient off-loading as appropriate and trained.
Restocking specified helicopter medical equipment and oxygen cylinders as appropriate and trained.
Escorting the medical team and patient to the hospital trauma lift and to the appropriate receiving department.
Communicate any deficiencies to other Helideck Crew Members
Work flows
There must be a full complement of all required trained staff on site during the agreed hours of operation.
Opening and closing of the helideck
Agreed and notified helideck opening hours are Mon to Fri 08::00 – 16:00 or daylight, whichever is the shortest
No service is provided on public / bank holidays.
The helideck will also be periodically closed for training or helideck maintenance.
Any unscheduled closures outside of normal operating hours will be communicated to the relevant control rooms and online notification systems:
EoE England Ambulance service control room.
London HEMS desk.
Helimed mutual aid online

The helideck Operations team will declare the helideck open as per SOP.  Internal notifications will also be made to clinical operations and the BICU. Should ED declare that Broomfield Hospital is unable to receive general emergency patients they should phone the helideck during deck operating hours. Notifications should also be made to the helideck if circumstances change

Primary and secondary burn transfers may still be brought into Broomfield Hospital in the event of ED restrictions if there is capacity within the Burns Service. The BICU will declare that they are able to receive patients when called by the Helideck and the Emergency Department.
Secondary transfers for burns patients will still follow direct
clinical referral to BICU
The Helideck will be closed at the time and in the manner described within the SOP the Helideck Ops team will notify the Broomfield Hospital clinical operations team & BICU when this is done).
Primary transfers
7.2.1 All patients within the usual catchment area of Broomfield may be retrieved according to clinical need.
7.2.2 Out of area primary burns transfers may be received at the discretion of the BICU and the ED (see BICU Primary Air Ambulance Transfer Protocol for further detail).
Helicopter landing

7.3.1 Prior to leaving the site of retrieval, the air ambulance medic will phone Broomfield ED with clinical details relevant to transfer. If a patient has suffered a primary burn injury, it is the responsibility of the ED to inform BICU in order that assistance for the Trusts trauma team can be provided.

7.3.2 The Helideck Ops room are normally notified by either Ambulance Control, BICU, Royal London Hems, or HEMS Pilot from Scene that they intend to come to the Hospital. The Helideck staff will then implement their ‘Call Out' Procedure noting that  there is a minimum of 10 minutes notice required for activation of the fire crew. Without the fire crew in attendance on the deck, and prepared, air craft cannot land.
7.3.3 The flight crew will transfer the patient from the helideck to the ED accompanied by a fire fighter from Broomfield.
7.3.4 The Emergency Department is responsible for ensuring that:
Appropriate data are recorded for every helicopter transfer to Broomfield;
The ED personnel are prepared to receive the patient from the air ambulance staff. The air ambulance team are expected to perform full clinical handover to Broomfield staff within the ED;
When indicated, a Trauma Call or cardiac arrest call will be made to ensure clinical teams attendance prior to patients arrival.
Secondary transfers into Broomfield
7.4.1 The referral should be made to either GICU or BICU in the usual manner.
7.4.2 The mode of transfer is ultimately made at the discretion of the consultant in charge of the patient's care.
7.4.3 When transferred by air ambulance, the usual SOP will be followed and the air crew will transfer the patient to either GICU or BICU as appropriate. The patient will NOT

be transferred to the ED unless there is a problem in flight that requires urgent consideration. In such cases, the ED should be notified at the earliest opportunity. (see BICU Air Ambulance Transfer Protocol).
Key relationships
Key operational requirements
Helideck Fire & Rescue Service
Fully equipped Emergency Department
Fully equipped GICU/BICU areas
Support from the Department of Anaesthesia
Dedicated office space
Access to ICT
Appropriate storage space
Teaching and education facilities
Effective links with Estates and Facilities
Hard and Soft FM services
8.1.1  Key relationships with other departments
Portering Services
ED
GICU
BICU
Ambulance Control at East of England
Specialist Referral Hospitals
Essex County Fire & Rescue Service
Civil Aviation Authority
HEMS providers.
Key requirements for facilities management (FM)
8.2.1 The unit has a dedicated cleaning service for effective decontamination of the helideck. This allows efficient use of the facility.
8.2.2 The Fire Fighting equipment is maintained by the Helideck Crew and external agencies as required.
8.2.3 For hospital maintained equipment that is used to support the helideck operations EBME will provide the support required.
Environmental requirements
These are fully documented within the helideck SOP.
Way finding
The GICU is signposted from all points of access to the hospital
BICU is signposted from all parts of access to the hospital
In all helideck transfers, at least one fire fighter, employed by the Trust or Bouygue will be available to direct the transfer crew to the appropriate location and support wayfinding.
Security requirements
Helideck Security
The helideck doors should be locked and access restricted unless there is flying activity.
All visitors to the helideck will report to the Helideck Fire Service Operations Office and follow the Helideck SOP thereafter.
Security for Patients
The service will be delivered in accordance, with and compliance to the Trust's Patient Safety Policies

The Helideck has restricted access: only Broomfield qualified and local authority (under Broomfield supervision) fire fighters are allowed airside as per Helideck SOP, trained clinical staff involved in the transfer of patients from Broomfield to other units via air ambulance also have access.
The Helideck Fire Service Operations Office has a security entry system preventing unwanted access
Security for Staff
The service will be delivered in accordance, with and compliance to the Trust's Security / Risk Management Policies.
Security of Information

The forms and data that relate to the operation of the helideck and to the fire fighters will be retained in a locked cabinet or in a secure file retained on the trust network in line with Trust information governance policies.
Manual Handling
The service will be delivered in accordance, with and in compliance with the Trust's Manual Handing Policies (covered by Broomfield mandatory training).
Fire Safety
The service will be compliant with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and procedures (covered by Broomfield mandatory training).
The detail of these items will then be developed as part of the separate Fire Safety Work Programme, as led by the Trust's Fire Officer
Aspects of fire safety specifically relating to the helideck are covered within the Helideck SOP.
IT requirements
ICT Requirements for the service include:
A quantity of PCs with office based software, available to all staff;
Telephone access throughout the helicopter service area;
Pager service;
There is a ‘red phone' link between the helideck and the Emergency Department. This will be used by the ED to notify the helideck that a landing is imminent.
Staffing
The current staffing of the helideck is as per the list:-
1 x Helideck Firefighter( full time);
4 x volunteer fire fighter;
1 x Helideck Fire Officer (Bank staff).
Equipment requirements
This is covered within the Helideck SOP and fulfils the standards for H1 category helidecks.
Contingency

If the helideck is declared non-operational; then internally withinBroomfield, there is a list of those that need to be informed so as to identify and rectify the problem. This document is contained within the Helideck SOP.
Training requirements
All staff within the helideck service will comply with the Trust Mandatory Training Programme.
Training for all staff involved in manning the helideck will be addressed within the Helideck SOP and its training manuals as required through regulations.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed

data.text: More frequent updates will be provided on request from the senior Trust management. Other audit specific topics will be developed learning from good practice of other units with helicopter landing decks and those required by the regulators.
All complaints, incidents will be investigated and responded to in line with MSE policies and procedures.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Health and Safety Committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and procedures. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Health and Safety Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 5)
References

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, (2004). Improving outcomes in head and neck cancers. Cancer service guideline [CSG6]. London:NICE. Available at: www.nice.org.uk/guidance/csg6

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, (2012). Healthcare associated infections: prevention and control in primary and community care. Clinical guideline [CG139]. London:NICE. Available at: www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg139
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, (2014). Head injury: assessment and early management. Clinical guideline [CG176]. London:NICE. Available at: www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg176

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, (2019). Stroke and transient ischaemic attack in over 16s: diagnosis and initial management . NICE guideline [NG128]. London:NICE. Available at: www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng128
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, (2014). Pressure ulcers: prevention and management. Clinical guideline [CG179]. London:NICE. Available at: www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg179
